questions.questionText: What must a licensee do when advertising a personally owned rental property?
options: A) Always include the firm’s name
B) Follow the National Association of REALTORS® Code of Ethics if applicable
C) Disclose lead-based paint hazards
D) File an advertisement approval form with the DSPS
questions.explanation: NAR Code of Ethics requires disclosure of licensed status when advertising personally owned property.

questions.questionText: What is the WB-37 Residential Listing Contract used for?
options: A) Selling residential property
B) Renting residential property
C) Listing commercial properties for sale
D) Listing vacant land for sale
questions.explanation: The WB-37 is used to list residential properties for rental purposes.

questions.questionText: What determines if a mobile home is considered real property?
options: A) Location of the home
B) Connection to utilities, foundation, and land ownership
C) Size of the mobile home
D) Age of the mobile home
questions.explanation: These three elements define whether a mobile home is part of the real estate.

questions.questionText: What is a tenant’s right under Wis. Stat. § 704.08 regarding a check-in sheet?
options: A) They must request it in writing
B) It is only available upon lease renewal
C) They have seven days to return it after occupancy
D) It is optional for the landlord to provide it
questions.explanation: The law requires landlords to provide new tenants a check-in sheet with seven days to return it.

questions.questionText: What must a seller of a condominium provide within 10 days of accepting an offer?
options: A) The condominium’s financial history
B) A copy of the property deed
C) Required condominium documents
D) An appraisal of the unit
questions.explanation: Sellers must provide the required documents within 10 days of accepting an offer.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a property management agreement?
options: A) To list a property for sale
B) To outline the responsibilities of a rental agent
C) To document the lease agreement with tenants
D) To structure the relationship between the property owner and the firm
questions.explanation: Property management agreements outline the firm’s responsibilities to the property owner.

questions.questionText: What is the first step in listing a farm property?
options: A) Completing a WB-1 Residential Listing Contract
B) Using a WB-2 Farm Listing Contract
C) Determining the value of the crops
D) Submitting an agricultural zoning request
questions.explanation: Farms are listed using the WB-2 Farm Listing Contract.

questions.questionText: What is the timeline for returning a tenant’s security deposit after vacating the premises?
options: A) 15 days
B) 21 days
C) 30 days
D) 45 days
questions.explanation: Security deposits must be returned within 21 days unless properly withheld.

questions.questionText: What type of account is appropriate for holding security deposits for property management?
options: A) Brokerage firm’s IBRETA account
B) Non-interest bearing trust account
C) General business account
D) Licensee’s personal account
questions.explanation: Security deposits must be held in a trust account for non-client funds.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee do when working with a buyer on vacant land?
options: A) Complete a WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase
B) Assess the land for past uses and potential issues
C) Survey the land for zoning restrictions
D) File a conservation easement
questions.explanation: Understanding the land’s past and intended uses is critical for drafting an effective offer.

questions.questionText: What defines a commercial transaction under Wis. Stat. § 779.32?
options: A) The presence of eight or fewer dwelling units
B) The inclusion of business assets in the sale
C) The property’s zoning classification
D) A contract with the local municipality
questions.explanation: Zoning classification helps define commercial transactions.

questions.questionText: What must a landlord provide to prospective tenants when collecting earnest money?
options: A) The rental agreement
B) A written receipt for the deposit
C) Proof of property insurance
D) An affidavit of ownership
questions.explanation: A receipt stating the deposit's purpose and amount is required.

questions.questionText: What is a "quit or pay" notice?
options: A) A warning about unauthorized tenants
B) A notice requiring rent payment or vacating the property
C) A 30-day termination notice
D) A notice of lease renewal options
questions.explanation: A "quit or pay" notice gives tenants a deadline to pay rent or vacate.

questions.questionText: When is a lead-based paint disclosure required?
options: A) For all residential properties
B) Only for properties built after 1978
C) For target housing built before 1978
D) Only when tenants request it
questions.explanation: Federal law requires lead-based paint disclosure for target housing built before 1978.

questions.questionText: What document does a buyer use to write an offer for a condominium unit?
options: A) WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase
B) WB-13 Vacant Land Offer to Purchase
C) WB-14 Residential Condominium Offer to Purchase
D) WB-15 Commercial Offer to Purchase
questions.explanation: WB-14 is the specific form for condominium transactions.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee include when advertising for tenants for a property owned by their business entity?
options: A) The property address only
B) The licensee’s name and contact information
C) The firm’s name or trade name as registered with the DSPS
D) A copy of the rental agreement
questions.explanation: A business entity must advertise in the firm’s name as registered with the DSPS.

questions.questionText: What is required if a licensee uses a WB-1 Residential Listing Contract and simultaneously lists the property for rent?
options: A) WB-13 Vacant Land Offer to Purchase
B) WB-37 Residential Listing Contract - Exclusive Right to Rent
C) A signed waiver from the seller
D) The WB-14 Condominium Offer to Purchase
questions.explanation: A WB-37 is required for rental listings.

questions.questionText: What determines if a person managing a rental property requires a real estate license?
options: A) The number of tenants
B) The manager’s compensation and activities
C) The owner’s consent
D) The age of the property
questions.explanation: Negotiating leases and signing contracts for compensation require a real estate license.

questions.questionText: When must a seller of a condominium provide an executive summary?
options: A) Only when the buyer requests it
B) At least 30 days before closing
C) Along with other condominium documents
D) Within 3 business days of receiving an offer
questions.explanation: The executive summary is part of the required condominium documents.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of an estoppel letter in commercial transactions?
options: A) To confirm zoning compliance
B) To certify facts about existing tenancies
C) To calculate property taxes
D) To disclose material defects
questions.explanation: Estoppel letters confirm details about tenants, such as rent and lease terms.

questions.questionText: What happens if a buyer receives incomplete condominium disclosure documents?
options: A) The seller is penalized
B) The buyer has five business days to request missing documents or rescind the offer
C) The sale is automatically canceled
D) The buyer has no recourse
questions.explanation: The buyer must act within five business days or the documents are deemed acceptable.

questions.questionText: What must be disclosed to tenants before signing a lease?
options: A) All future rent increases
B) Name and address of the property owner or authorized agent
C) A detailed maintenance schedule
D) A list of the property’s previous tenants
questions.explanation: The property owner or agent’s contact details must be disclosed.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the WB-15 Commercial Offer to Purchase's environmental contingency?
options: A) To ensure compliance with ADA requirements
B) To assess the property’s environmental condition and risks
C) To allocate costs for future renovations
D) To transfer zoning rights
questions.explanation: The environmental contingency protects buyers from environmental risks.

questions.questionText: How are tenant security deposits handled for properties owned by a licensee?
options: A) Deposited into the firm’s general account
B) Held in a real estate trust account or owner’s account per the lease agreement
C) Paid directly to the landlord in cash
D) Transferred to the DSPS
questions.explanation: Security deposits must be held in a designated account based on the lease terms.

questions.questionText: Which form is used to list a farm property?
options: A) WB-1 Residential Listing Contract
B) WB-2 Farm Listing Contract
C) WB-3 Vacant Land Listing Contract
D) WB-5 Commercial Listing Contract
questions.explanation: The WB-2 is tailored to agricultural properties.

questions.questionText: What does a “Proposed Use Contingency” in the WB-13 Vacant Land Offer to Purchase address?
options: A) Zoning restrictions, permits, and environmental issues
B) Title insurance requirements
C) Property tax assessments
D) Availability of public utilities
questions.explanation: The contingency ensures the land can be used as intended.

questions.questionText: What type of auction allows a seller to set a minimum acceptable bid?
options: A) Absolute auction
B) Reserve auction
C) Open auction
D) Silent auction
questions.explanation: A reserve auction requires a minimum bid to sell the property.

questions.questionText: How can a buyer rescind an offer on a time-share purchase?
options: A) By filing a formal complaint
B) Within five business days of signing the offer
C) Within 48 hours of signing the offer
D) Only if the seller agrees
questions.explanation: Time-share purchases have a five-day rescission period.

questions.questionText: What is the timeline for completing promised repairs in a rental agreement?
options: A) No timeline is required
B) Within 30 days of the agreement
C) As specified in writing by the landlord
D) Before the tenant moves in
questions.explanation: Written repair promises must include a completion timeline.

questions.questionText: What must a firm’s supervising broker ensure for every associated licensee?
options: A) Access to a local real estate association
B) Proper licensing and compliance with rules
C) Payment of licensing fees by the firm
D) Use of independent contractor agreements only
questions.explanation: Supervising brokers must ensure that all associated licensees are properly licensed and compliant.

questions.questionText: What must be included in the WB-12 Farm Offer to Purchase for clarity in fixture inclusion?
options: A) Detailed inventory of machinery
B) Affirmation of annual crops as personal property unless agreed otherwise
C) A list of all livestock
D) Evidence of soil quality tests
questions.explanation: Annual crops are not fixtures unless specified in the contract.

questions.questionText: How is a licensee’s competence in business opportunity transactions established?
options: A) By passing a specialty exam
B) By consulting a qualified expert if lacking experience
C) Through continuing education credits
D) By submitting a request to the DSPS
questions.explanation: Licensees must seek expertise if they are not competent in business transactions.

questions.questionText: What is the key consideration in drafting an offer for vacant land with potential contamination?
options: A) Proposed Use Contingency and environmental testing
B) Title insurance coverage
C) Approval from the local zoning board
D) Inclusion of soil testing permits
questions.explanation: Environmental testing ensures the land is suitable for the buyer’s intended use.

questions.questionText: What are the elements of an executive summary for condominium sales?
options: A) Property history and maintenance records
B) Parking, pet rules, rental restrictions, and reserve account details
C) The seller’s previous utility bills
D) Market valuation of comparable units
questions.explanation: The executive summary outlines critical condominium details for buyers.

questions.questionText: What does strict responsibility misrepresentation require in real estate transactions?
options: A) Intent to deceive
B) Negligence on the licensee’s part
C) Economic interest and false statement as fact
D) Buyer agreement on undisclosed terms
questions.explanation: Strict responsibility holds licensees accountable even without intent to deceive.

questions.questionText: What is required for trust account record retention?
options: A) Records must be retained for at least five years
B) Records must be retained electronically for two years or more
C) Records must be archived by DSPS within three months
D) Records must be submitted annually to the DSPS
questions.explanation: Records may be kept electronically for two years, per regulations.

questions.questionText: What is the maximum civil forfeiture for a property owner violating Wis. Admin. Code Ch. ATCP 134?
options: C) $10,000 per violation
questions.explanation: Violations can result in civil forfeitures up to $10,000 per infraction.

questions.questionText: How should a licensee handle historic property tax incentives?
options: A) Apply directly on behalf of the client
B) Refer the client to the Wisconsin Historical Society
C) Provide a tax adjustment at closing
D) Include tax incentives in the listing price
questions.explanation: Referral ensures accurate information about historic tax incentives.

questions.questionText: What must be included when listing a business for sale without real estate?
options: A) Property inspection reports
B) Allocation of purchase price to goodwill and inventory
C) Proof of business income tax filing
D) Zoning approval for future business use
questions.explanation: Allocation of price components is critical in business sales.

questions.questionText: What is required to transfer contracts during a broker's business closure?
options: A) Client consent and formal notifications
B) Automatic transfer to the firm’s successor
C) Approval by the DSPS
D) Immediate reassignment by the supervising broker
questions.explanation: Contracts require client consent and clear communication.

questions.questionText: What liability arises if a contractor improperly remediates lead-based paint?
options: A) None, as contractors hold sole responsibility
B) The licensee and firm may share liability if they hired the contractor
C) The DSPS is notified for resolution
D) The tenant must pursue the contractor directly
questions.explanation: Improper remediation can result in liability for the hiring firm or licensee.

questions.questionText: What is the main distinction between a commercial and a business transaction?
options: A) Inclusion of licenses and personal property in business transactions
B) Zoning compliance in commercial transactions
C) Use of different listing contracts
D) Buyer’s intent to modify the property
questions.explanation: Business transactions often involve personal property and operational assets.

questions.questionText: What triggers the statute of limitations for legal action against a licensee?
options: A) The closing date or termination of an agency agreement
B) The listing contract's signing date
C) Discovery of fraud
D) Notification from the DSPS
questions.explanation: The two-year period begins with the closing or agency agreement termination.

questions.questionText: What document is critical for auction transactions?
options: A) Bidder’s package
B) Inspection report
C) Lead-based paint waiver
D) WB-12 Farm Offer to Purchase
questions.explanation: The bidder’s package contains essential details for auction participants.

questions.questionText: What contingency ensures compliance with ADA accessibility for a commercial property?
options: A) Document review contingency
B) Accessibility contingency
C) Environmental contingency
D) Building inspection contingency
questions.explanation: Accessibility contingencies address ADA compliance issues.
